items.content:
This unit is called 'Reproduction'.

Everyone dies sooner or later. Because people reproduce, there are always new people to replace them.

For this unit you need your textbook (Your Biology HAVO|VWO). Make sure you always have it with you during class.

Most of the exercises we will make on the tablet. So, also make sure to bring it to class and that it is charged. Furthermore, you will need a notebook to take notes and to copy some of the answers from the exercises. On a regular base it can happen that we will have a drawing exercise, therefore also bring your pen, pencil, eraser and protractor triangle.

The basics:

Bas 1: You are changing...

Bas 2: The male reproductive system

Bas 3: The female reproductive system

Bas 4: Menstruation

Bas 5: Sexuality

Bas 6: Birth control

Bas 7: Pregnancy and childbirth

Bas 8: Sexually transmitted infections

Bas 9: Other methods of birth control

Bas 10: Other sexually transmitted infections
Puberty in boys

content.body:
The figure below is a drawing of a naked man. Write down the correct sexual characteristics next to the numbers. Say after each
characteristic whether it is a primary (P) or secondary (S) characteristic.

1. -

2. -

3. -

4. -

5. -

6. -

items.content:
Answer the following questions.
1. Name three physical changes that both boys and girls go through in puberty.

2. Is the hair growth in the armpits a sexual characteristic? Explain your answer.

Questions 3 to 5 are about the article below.
3. Give an example of an emotional change in Susie.

4. Give an example of a social change in Susie.

5. Give an example of an emotional change in Bob.

content.body:
Complete the table about sexual characteristics in women.

Primary sexual characteristics in women Secondary sexual characteristics in women

items.content:
Answer questions 1 to 3 using figure 4 in your textbook.
1. In what age range can girls start to develop breasts?

2. At what age on average does the penis start to grow more in boys?

3. A girl starts to develop breasts at the age of 9.
Is that early or late compared with most girls of her age? Explain your answer.

Answer questions 4 and 5 using the figure on the right.
4. Who grow quicker on average during puberty, boys or girls? Explain your answer.

5. Are there also girls who grow faster during puberty than some boys? Explain your answer.

Read basic 1.

Thread exercise

With each basic you continue with this exercise. You have three choices:

A. Making a mindmap

  • Use a white sheet of A3-paper and make a mindmap.
  • In the middle should be the unit title.
  • Write all blue words on your paper and connect them when possible.
  • Write other important words on you paper as well.

B. Summarize

  • Use a separate paper with lines or use a separate area in you notebook.
  • Write down all blue words and add the meaning or description behind them. Sometimes it is not just the meaning of the word, then write down why the word is important.
  • Write down other important words as well.

C. Flash cards

  • This is actually very similar to summarizing, however, you write the words and descriptions on different sides of a coloured paper. The teacher has them for you.
  • Write down all blue words and add the meaning or description behind them. Sometimes it is not just the meaning of the word, then write down why the word is important.
  • Write down other important words as well.
Watch the youtube movie about the male reproductive system.

Answer the following questions.
1. What is the function of hormones?

2. What produces hormones?

3. Which endocrine gland makes the testes start creating sperm cells in puberty?

Use the article below for questions 4 and 5.
4. Explain why boys can become more muscular by using anabolic steroids.

5. Give one reason why anabolic steroids are banned.

6. An enlarged prostate gland (see figure on the right) can cause problems when urinating. Enlarged prostate glands are a problem among older men in particular.
Explain why an enlarged prostate gland can cause problems with urinating.

7. List three ways in which a boy or man might get an ejaculation.

prompt.body: Descriptions are given below of parts of the male reproductive system. Add the correct words to the descriptions.

content.body: External primary sexual characteristic of the male
Organ that adds fluid to sperm cells to make them move
Fluid that contains sperm cells, fluid from seminal vesicles and prostate
Fold of skin that covers the head of the penis
Another name for the male sex cells
Urine and semen is transported through this
Fold of skin that keeps sperm production at a low temperature

Watch the youtube movie about the female reproductive system.

prompt.body: Descriptions are given below of parts of the female reproductive system. Add the correct words to the descriptions.

content.body: Receives stimuli that could result in an orgasm
Semen enters this part during sexual intercourse
This part is where the development of the ova takes place
This part is where the baby develops before birth

Creating the mucus that makes the entrance to the vagina
smooth

items.content:
Answer the following questions.

1. Naomi has had regular ovulations (every four weeks) since her 15th birthday. Her menopause starts on about her 45th birthday and stops when she turns 50. She has never been pregnant.
Roughly how many ovulations will there have been in her body between her 15th and 45th birthdays?

2. Could Naomi still have ovulations after her 45th birthday? Explain your answer.

3. The figure on the right shows an ovum and sperm cells.
Is it a drawing of a moment after fertilisation has taken place? Explain your answer.

4. Can fertilisation take place in a woman's body (in normal circumstances) after the menopause? Explain your answer.

5. Why can an ovum only be fertilised by one sperm cell?

6. The second figure on the right shows a cluster of cells in the uterus.
Is it a drawing of a moment after implantation has taken place? Explain your answer.

Use the following information to answer questions 7 to 9.
The figure below shows a drawing of the reproductive system and excretory system of a mouse. The structure of the reproductive system of a mouse is slightly different to the structure of the human reproductive system because a mouse has two uteruses. The functions of the different parts are the same in other respects.

7. In which part does the development of the ova take place?

8. In which part does fertilisation take place?

9. In which part does implantation take place?
Watch the youtube movie about the hymen and answer the question below.

content.body:
Click on the correct words; egg cells or sperm cells.

These are the biggest sex cells: Egg cells Sperm cells
These cells can move of their own accord: Egg cells Sperm cells
These sex cells contain food reserves: Egg cells Sperm cells
These sex cells are produced in the greatest quantity: Egg cells Sperm cells

items.content:
Check your knowledge with the following quizzes:

1. Puberty and menstrual cycle at ProProfs (click on 'Start' to start the quiz)

2. The menstrual cycle quiz at EmpowerHER.com (click on 'Take Quiz' to start the quiz)

Read basic 5.

Thread exercise

With each basic you continue with this exercise. You have three choices:

A. Making a mindmap

  • Use a white sheet of A3-paper and make a mindmap.
  • In the middle should be the unit title.
  • Write all blue words on your paper and connect them when possible.
  • Write other important words on you paper as well.

B. Summarize

  • Use a separate paper with lines or use a separate area in you notebook.
  • Write down all blue words and add the meaning or description behind them. Sometimes it is not just the meaning of the word, then write down why the word is important.
  • Write down other important words as well.

C. Flash cards

  • This is actually very similar to summarizing, however, you write the words and descriptions on different sides of a coloured paper. The teacher has them for you.
  • Write down all blue words and add the meaning or description behind them. Sometimes it is not just the meaning of the word, then write down why the word is important.
  • Write down other important words as well.

Answer the following questions.

1. Give three ways in which sexuality can play a role in someone's life.

2. State three opinions about sexual intercourse and relationships.

3. Six statements are given below. Say for each statement whether or not you agree. Also say why you agree or disagree with the statement.

1. Different people have very different sexual preferences and ideas about sexuality. Some people think that sexual intercourse belongs within marriage, while others see nothing wrong in sex with someone they only met an hour earlier. You also have heterosexuals, homosexuals, bisexuals and transsexuals. That is why you should treat everyone with respect as long as they are not hurting anyone else; otherwise you yourself would be hurting them.
I agree/disagree, because ...

2. If a boy in your class is a transvestite, he should not wear a skirt to school.
I agree/disagree, because ...

3. You see what a sexual relationship should be like by watching porn on the Internet.
I agree/disagree, because ...

4. If my best friend turned out to be homosexual, I would find that quite difficult to deal with.
I agree/disagree, because ...

5. It is perfectly normal for homosexuals to be open about their homosexuality; after all, heterosexuals are open as well.
I agree/disagree, because ...

6. I do not think it would be a problem if I started a relationship with someone who is four years older.
I agree/disagree, because ...

Below you can find ten statements (A to J). Make a list in your notebook stating with which statements you agree and with which ones you disagree.

A. If a boy treats a girl to an evening out, it's only reasonable for the boy to expect the girl to have sex with him in return.

B. Pinching someone's bottom is so harmless that a boy can do that to a girl.

C. It's OK to get undressed in front of a webcam for a good friend.

D. If you've been sexually abused, it's better not to mention it to anyone because that only makes you drag up all the hurt again.

E. Rapists are nearly always solitary, unmarried older men.

F. The most important thing in sex is that you personally enjoy it.

G. It's OK for a girl to flirt with a boy.

H. You need to say well in time where your own limits are when it comes to sex (see the Dutch posters in the figure below), otherwise you can easily do something you might regret later.

I. A girl who dresses provocatively is asking to be raped.

J. You can recognise a loverboy immediately from his behaviour.

You should do this exercise in a group of up to four classmates.
You said whether you agreed or disagreed with various statements in exercises 21 and 22.

- Compare your answers to exercises 21 and 22 with those of the other pupils in your group.
- Choose three statements where you have different opinions.
- Write down the statement's letter or number.
- Give arguments for and against these statements.
- Discuss the statements further with the group. Choose one person to lead the discussion.

Your teacher will tell you whether you need to give a talk to the class about the statements.

Read basic 6 and answer the following questions.

1. Why is coitus interruptus (the withdrawal method) not a reliable method of birth control (contraception)?

2. Another disadvantage of the withdrawal method is that the man has to have sufficient self-control. Explain why.

3. How does the pill stop a possible fertilisation?

4. What beneficial side-effect can the pill have for a woman?

5. What adverse side-effects can the pill have?

The figure on the right shows the length of the menstrual cycle in relation to age for five women. Questions 1 to 3 are about this figure.

6. At which age is the change in the length of the menstrual cycle bigger: at age 16 or at age 32?

7. At which age is it more difficult to determine the fertile period: at age 16 or at age 32?

8. The rhythm method is unreliable at any age, but at which age is the rhythm method more unreliable: at age 16 or at age 32? Explain your answer.

9. A boy says that the investigation described in figure 35 of your textbook shows that you can see from a woman's face when she is in her fertile period.

Give an argument from this investigation that shows why this is a very unreliable method.

content.body:
There are different versions of the pill. The figure on the bottom of this page shows you part of the patient information leaflet for a certain version of the pill. This part of the patient information leaflet tells the woman what to do if she has not been taking her pills when she should. That is because you have an increased risk of becoming pregnant if you forget to take a pill.

- Below you can see three women. They have all forgotten to take one or more pills.

Five options, labelled A through to E, are listed in patient information leaflet.

Write down the letter for the option that each woman should choose.

Alison:

Imogen:

Ashley:

items.content: Patient information leaflet

Answer the following questions.

1. Within what period after having sex should you take the morning-after pill for it to be most reliable?

2. Why is it not a good idea for a woman who has sexual intercourse to assume she can just have the morning-after pill the next day?
3. Say which parts are removed in vacuum aspiration.

4. Now see how well you score on this contraception quiz at University of Rochester. Write down the number of answers you had answered correctly!

Read basic 6.

  • Write down other important words as well.

To become pregnant a sperm cells needs to find the egg cell.

Watch the movie about Fertilization on YouTube.

Answer the following questions.

content.body: the swimming action of a sperm
the joining of an egg and a sperm
the release of an egg from the ovary
the nine months that a baby develops in the womb

prompt.body: 2. Egg and sperm are special cells because _____.

content.body: they only contain half of the genetic information that your other body cells contain
they can divide to make more eggs and sperm
they do not contain any genetic information like the rest of your cells

prompt.body: 3. Sperm are odd-shaped cells that have a head and a _____.

items.content:
Watch the videos about pregnancy and childbirth below.

1. From fertilisation to implantation to embryo.

Answer the following questions.

A woman has marked when she had her menstruation in the calendar on the right. Her menstruations are very regular - every four weeks.
1. When does she expect her next menstruation?

2. When will ovulation probably take place?

3. Suppose that this woman has sexual intercourse and the ovum is fertilised.
In which week is implantation in the uterus lining likely to take place?

4. In which month will the child probably be born?

5. Three women do the pregnancy test described in figure below. The results are shown in the figure on the right. Write down the outcome of each test (1 to 3).


6. When women are pregnant, they produce the pregnancy hormone hCG. Pregnancy tests detect this hormone hCG in the pregnant woman's urine. The earliest point at which such tests can give a
positive result is on the first day that menstruation should have started again. The graph in the figure below shows the change in the amount of hCG in the blood of a pregnant woman. Four points in time are labelled with letters.
Which letter shows the earliest moment when a pregnancy test can give a reliable positive result?

7. Pregnancy lasts forty weeks on average. This period is calculated from the first day of the last
menstruation (see figure).
Does that mean the baby is forty weeks old when it is born? Explain your answer.

8. How long does a pregnancy last on average, counting from the implantation?

prompt.body:
The figure on the right shows a schematic drawing of a foetus in the womb (uterus).
- Combine the names of the parts with the numbers.

items.content:
Answer the following questions.

1. Where does the first division of the fertilised ovum take place in humans?

2. Where does the embryo get its nutrients from during the first few weeks of the pregnancy?

3. Where does the embryo get its nutrients from after the first few weeks?

4. Does the mother's blood reach the embryo through the placenta? Explain your answer.

5. What is the function of the amniotic sac and the amniotic fluid?

6. Pregnant women frequently have to visit the toilet more often, usually to urinate small amounts.
Explain why pregnant women may have to urinate more often than normal.

Explain why it is important for a pregnant woman to have a healthy lifestyle (see the article below). Use the following words: development of the baby - harmful substances such as alcohol and nicotine - placenta - the embryo's blood - the mother's blood. Start your sentence with:

A pregnant woman should have a healthy lifestyle because ...

Answer the following questions.

The graph in the figure below shows the length and weight of an unborn baby during pregnancy.

1. How long is the unborn baby when it is twenty weeks old?

2. Three periods in the pregnancy are weeks 4 to 8, weeks 20 to 24 and weeks 36 to 40. In which of those three periods is the increase in weight greatest?

3. In which of those three periods is the increase in length greatest?

content.body:
Complete the sentences.

During , the lower part of the uterus becomes wider. During this phase, can occur. These are contractions of the muscles in the wall of the uterus that take place at intervals. The may break during this stage (the 'waters breaking'), and the then flows out of the vagina. The phase that follows is called the . The muscles of the also contract in this phase of labour and there will then be . These push the baby out. In a normal birth, the appears first. In a , the rump or a foot will come out first. A transverse presentation means that the baby will be born by . After the birth, the has to be removed from the airways. The is clamped off and cut. The end of it that is attached to the baby dries out and falls off. The scar that this leaves is called the . Contractions of the push out the and the remains of the umbilical cord and the amniotic sac. This is referred to as the .

items.content:
Use figure 54 of your textbook to answer the questions 1 to 4.

1. Anne, the midwife, says that Mrs Williams was allowed to push actively with the expulsion contractions. What phase of labour had then started?

2. Which two groups of muscles contract together during the expulsion contractions?

3. How will the baby in the figure above on the left be born: vaginally or via a caesarean? Explain your answer.

4. In the figure above, number 1 and 2 are two drawings of a woman's pelvis. Which woman is more likely to have to have a caesarean? Explain your answer.

Use the newspaper article below to answer the questions 5 to 7.

5. Which stage of labour had started shortly before the man and woman drove away from their house?

6. Which stage of labour had started at the moment when they were stopped by the police?

7. Which stage of labour started in the hospital's delivery room?

Read basic 7.

Thread exercise

With each basic you continue with this exercise. You have three choices:

A. Making a mindmap

  • Use a white sheet of A3-paper and make a mindmap.
  • In the middle should be the unit title.
  • Write all blue words on your paper and connect them when possible.
  • Write other important words on you paper as well.

B. Summarize

  • Write down all blue words and add the meaning or description behind them. Sometimes it is not just the meaning of the word, then write down why the word is important.
  • Write down other important words as well.

C. Flash cards

  • This is actually very similar to summarizing, however, you write the words and descriptions on different sides of a coloured paper. The teacher has them for you.
  • Write down all blue words and add the meaning or description behind them. Sometimes it is not just the meaning of the word, then write down why the word is important.
  • Write down other important words as well.

Answer the following questions.

1. What distinguishes sexually transmitted infections from other infectious diseases?

2. Why is it difficult to determine the number of people who are infected with chlamydia?

3. A boy who does not want to use a condom says to his girlfriend, "I'm certain I don't have an STI, because I don't have any symptoms. So there's no need for a condom." What could (or should) the girl say in reply?

4. The poster on the right is a Dutch poster warning about chlamydia. Explain what is meant by the slogan "If you want children later, use a condom now!".

5. Explain why there are no specific symptoms associated with AIDS.

6. Does someone who is seropositive have AIDS? Explain your answer.

7. Why is it very difficult to develop a medicine to cure AIDS?

Use figure 57 of your textbook for answering questions 8 and 9.

8. In sub-Saharan Africa, the number of seropositive people and AIDS patients increased most in 2012. Calculate how many people that is.

9. In the figure, you can read that there was an increase of 2.3 million new HIV infections in 2012. In 2011, the number of people with AIDS infections was estimated at 34.6 million. In 2012, the figure was 35.3 million. That is not an increase of 2.3 million. Give an explanation for this.

The article below shows part of a flyer about AIDS (and other STIs). Use the article to answer the questions below.

1. What is the most important rule for safe sex?

2. Male homosexuals often have anal sex. What special measures can they take to avoid HIV infection?

3. If you do not use a condom or oral barrier ("dental dam" for oral sex), what other forms of intimate physical contact can you have without running the risk of an AIDS infection?

4. Is there any risk of AIDS if you have a steady relationship and only have sex with a single person?

1. Use the Internet to find out what one of the following STIs involves:
- syphilis;
- HPV;
- scabies;
- pubic lice;
- candida;
- trichomonas;

- bacterial vaginosis.

2. Make a presentation about the chosen STI on a poster, a digital presentation or a short one-page report.

3. Give your presentation a clear structure. It should cover at least the following:
- the pathogen;
- the symptoms;

- the possible treatment.

Read basic 8.

heading.content: Bas 9: Other methods of birth control

items.content:
Use the investigation in figure 68 in your textbook to answer the following questions.

1. Draw a conclusion from the investigation by completing the rest of the table. Fill in the correct methods for a, b and c. The table categorises methods of contraception in terms of their reliability.

Average actual use Pearl index Assessment Contraceptive methods
0-3 very reliable a.
3 to 5 reasonably reliable b.
greater than 5 unreliable c.


2. The investigation shows that the condom and the female condom are not the most reliable methods of contraception in practice. Even so, it may be sensible to choose one of these methods of contraception. Explain why.

3. One third of pill users forget to take the pill regularly and on time. Will this make the Pearl index for actual use of the pill higher or lower? Explain your answer.

4. In a specific country, 90 out of a group of 1382 women who used condoms became pregnant over the course of eighteen months. Calculate the Pearl index for condoms in that country (disregarding the decimal places). You can calculate the Pearl index as follows:

5. The actual use Pearl index for condoms in another country is 6. Over a timeframe of twelve months, 950 women were followed. Calculate how many women became pregnant during this study. (Your maths lessons must have covered how to solve equations.)

Hint: Let us call the number of pregnant women 'a'.

Make a table for all methods of contraception containing the following columns:

Method of contraception - How it works - Advantages - Disadvantages

Read basic 9.

Check these movies to learn more about hormones.

values.value:
1. – The body starts to grow quickly (the growth spurt).
– Hair starts to appear in the armpits and around the sexual organs.
– The reproductive organs start to function.
2. No, it's not a characteristic that lets you recognise a person's sex.
3. Susie now buys her own clothes (is more independent).
4. Susie now has a different attitude to her mother. She finds the clothes that her mother buys ridiculous now, but she didn't when she was at primary school.
5. He has fallen in love and sexuality (kissing) has become important.

content.body:
1. - The body starts to grow quickly (the growth spurt).
- Hair starts to appear in the armpits and around the sexual organs.
- The reproductive organs start to function.
2. No, it's not a characteristic that lets you recognise a person's sex.
3. Susie now buys her own clothes (is more independent).
4. Susie now has a different attitude to her mother. She finds the clothes that her mother buys ridiculous now, but she didn't when she was at primary school.
5. He has fallen in love and sexuality (kissing) has become important.

values.value:
1. Between ages 8 and 13.
2. At age 13.
3. That is early, because the average age at which the breasts start to develop is 10.5.
4. Boys grow quicker on average: 10 cm per year. Girls grow more slowly on average: 9 cm per year.
5. Yes, because these are averages. So there are also girls who grow 10 cm per year for example and boys who only grow 9 cm per year.

content.body:
1. Between ages 8 and 13.
2. At age 13.
3. That is early, because the average age at which the breasts start to develop is 10.5.
4. Boys grow quicker on average: 10 cm per year. Girls grow more slowly on average: 9 cm per year.
5. Yes, because these are averages. So there are also girls who grow 10 cm per year for example and boys who only grow 9 cm per year.

values.value:
1. Hormones regulate all kinds of processes in your body.
2. Endocrine glands.
3. The pituitary.
4. Anabolic steroids copy the effect of hormones, causing boys in puberty to develop secondary sexual characteristics. In boys, one of these secondary sexual characteristics is developing more muscles.
5. Using anabolic steroids can lead to all kinds of illnesses and health problems.
6. If the prostate gland is enlarged, it may press on the urethra and close it. This makes it more difficult to transport urine from the bladder.
7. – By sexual intercourse.

– By masturbation.

– As a ‘wet dream’ (spontaneous ejaculation).

content.body:
1. Hormones regulate all kinds of processes in your body.
2. Endocrine glands.
3. The pituitary.
4. Anabolic steroids copy the effect of hormones, causing boys in puberty to develop secondary sexual characteristics. In boys, one of these secondary sexual characteristics is developing more muscles.
5. Using anabolic steroids can lead to all kinds of illnesses and health problems.
6. If the prostate gland is enlarged, it may press on the urethra and close it. This makes it more difficult to transport urine from the bladder.
7. - By sexual intercourse.

- By masturbation.

- As a 'wet dream' (spontaneous ejaculation).

values.value:
1. There will have been 30 years of ovulations between her 15th and 45th birthdays. Each year there will have been about 52÷4 = 13 ovulations.
In 30 years there will therefore have been about 30×13 = 390 ovulations.
2. Yes, because hormone production is less after Naomi's 45th birthday but it has not yet stopped entirely. So there could still be ovulations.
3. No, because the nucleus of the male sex cell has not yet fused with the nucleus of the female sex cell.
4. No, because the ovulations stop then.
5. Because the outer layer of the ovum becomes impenetrable once the head of a sperm cell has entered the ovum.
6. No, because the cluster of cells has not yet become attached to the uterus lining.
7. In part 1.
8. In part 2.
9. In part 3.

In 30 years there will therefore have been about 30×13 = 390 ovulations.

5. Because the outer layer of the ovum becomes impenetrable once the head of a sperm cell has entered the ovum.
6. No, because the cluster of cells has not yet become attached to the uterus lining.
7. In part 1.

values.value:
1. No, because it is a piece of tissue with an opening that the penis can already go through, even the first time that you have sexual intercourse.
Most of the time it has already been torn or stretched by physcial activity, tampon use or masturbation.

values.value:
1. Because fluid with sperm cells may already have left the penis before the man ejaculates.
2. The man has to remove his penis from the vagina in time.
3. The pill contains hormones that stop ovulation from taking place in the woman’s body.
4. Menstruation can become less severe.
5. Nausea, headaches, weight gain or a feeling of tension in the breasts.
6. At age 16.

8. At age 16, because that is when the length of the menstrual cycle changes most, which makes it even more difficult to determine when the fertile period is.
9. People cannot tell when a woman is in her fertile period in 45% of the cases.

2 Test was not carried out properly: invalid test .
3 Pregnant .

values.value:
1. In the Fallopian tube.
2. From the uterus lining.
3. The embryo gets nutrients from the mother’s blood via the placenta.
4. No, because the mother’s blood remains separated from the embryo’s blood by thin membranes.
5. The amniotic sac and the amniotic fluid protect the embryo from knocks, dehydration and temperature changes.
6. Because the uterus/foetus grows and puts pressure on the bladder.

content.body:
1. In the Fallopian tube.
2. From the uterus lining.
3. The embryo gets nutrients from the mother's blood via the placenta.
4. No, because the mother's blood remains separated from the embryo's blood by thin membranes.
5. The amniotic sac and the amniotic fluid protect the embryo from knocks, dehydration and temperature changes.
6. Because the uterus/foetus grows and puts pressure on the bladder.

values.value: A pregnant woman should have a healthy lifestyle because  harmful substances such as alcohol and nicotine can get into the embryo’s blood from the mother’s blood via the placenta. These substances are bad for the development of the baby.

content.body: A pregnant woman should have a healthy lifestyle because harmful substances such as alcohol and nicotine can get into the embryo's blood from the mother's blood via the placenta. These substances are bad for the development of the baby.

values.value:
1. You can only get sexually transmitted infections through intimate physical contact with an infected person.
2. Because many of the people who are infected do not have any symptoms. Two thirds of all infected women and half of all infected men do not notice anything.
3. In some STIs, it can take a long time before you get any symptoms. So you might not necessarily know that you have an STI. And in the meantime you could infect other people. So having no symptoms does not mean a thing.
4. If you use a condom, you reduce the risk of getting a chlamydia infection. An untreated chlamydia infection can cause infertility in women.
5. There are no specific symptoms because it affects your immune system. You are then susceptible to all kinds of other illnesses with their own associated symptoms.
6. No, because that person is infected by the AIDS virus without any symptoms being noticeable.
7. Because the AIDS virus is continually changing slightly.
8. In 2012, the number increased by 7%.    

So the number in 2011 is 25,000,000 ÷ 1.07 = 23,364,485.    

The number in 2012 therefore increased by 25,000,000 - 23,364,485 = 1,635,515, which is roughly 1.6 million people.

9. In 2012, 1.6 million people died of AIDS.

content.body:
1. You can only get sexually transmitted infections through intimate physical contact with an infected person.
2. Because many of the people who are infected do not have any symptoms. Two thirds of all infected women and half of all infected men do not notice anything.
3. In some STIs, it can take a long time before you get any symptoms. So you might not necessarily know that you have an STI. And in the meantime you could infect other people. So having no symptoms does not mean a thing.
4. If you use a condom, you reduce the risk of getting a chlamydia infection. An untreated chlamydia infection can cause infertility in women.
5. There are no specific symptoms because it affects your immune system. You are then susceptible to all kinds of other illnesses with their own associated symptoms.
6. No, because that person is infected by the AIDS virus without any symptoms being noticeable.
7. Because the AIDS virus is continually changing slightly.
8. In 2012, the number increased by 7%.

So the number in 2011 is 25,000,000 ÷ 1.07 = 23,364,485.

The number in 2012 therefore increased by 25,000,000 - 23,364,485 = 1,635,515, which is roughly 1.6 million people.

9. In 2012, 1.6 million people died of AIDS.

values.value:
1. Always use a condom until both have taken an STI test and then also get a favourable result three months later.
2. Use extra strong condoms and plenty of lubricant.
3. You can kiss, cuddle, stroke, massage or masturbate each other without any risk of an AIDS infection.
4. The risk of AIDS then depends on the risks that you and your partner have been exposed to in the past.

content.body:
1. Always use a condom until both have taken an STI test and then also get a favourable result three months later.
2. Use extra strong condoms and plenty of lubricant.
3. You can kiss, cuddle, stroke, massage or masturbate each other without any risk of an AIDS infection.
4. The risk of AIDS then depends on the risks that you and your partner have been exposed to in the past.

values.value:
1a. contraceptive injection, sterilisation, NuvaRing, IUD (coil)
  b. the pill, condom, female condom
  c. rhythm method, withdrawal method
2. They are the only contraceptive methods that protect against sexually transmitted infections.
3. Forgetting to take the pill is a mistake by the user. As a result, the number of unwanted pregnancies will increase. The actual use Pearl index will therefore be higher.
4. ( (90 × 12) / (1382 × 18) ) × 100 = 4.3  Rounded off, the Pearl index for condoms in that country is 4.

5.

content.body:
1a. contraceptive injection, sterilisation, NuvaRing, IUD (coil)
b. the pill, condom, female condom
c. rhythm method, withdrawal method
2. They are the only contraceptive methods that protect against sexually transmitted infections.
3. Forgetting to take the pill is a mistake by the user. As a result, the number of unwanted pregnancies will increase. The actual use Pearl index will therefore be higher.
4. ( (90 × 12) / (1382 × 18) ) × 100 = 4.3 Rounded off, the Pearl index for condoms in that country is 4.
